subject: Re: [junit] Where am I going wrong?
msgSnippet: ... Not with this information. Can you show us the specific test failures? We have no idea how your code actually behaves (was MHHERegistrar does, for
messageBody:
mcgqa wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I have 2 objectives for my testcase below
> 1) to test the registration process
> 2) to test the duplicated user
>
> when I run the test, I am getting either a null value for loginid or
> a totally new in value for dupLoginId and my assertion is failing
> when the method testRegisterDuplicatedUser() is executed. Can
> somebody tell me why?

Not with this information. Can you show us the specific test failures?
We have no idea how your code actually behaves (was MHHERegistrar does,
for example).

Still, there are a few things. My comments below.

> This is my first post to this forum. Is this the right forum to ask
> such questions?

Yes, it is.

I recommend going to http://www.diasparsoftware.com and finding the
article "JUnit: A Starter Guide". It may help you with this.

Good luck.


> *** various required imports ***
> public class MHHERegistrarTest extends TestCase {
>
> private MHHERegistrar mhheUsrReg;
> private UserAccount userAccount;
> String newLoginId = "sri"+(int)(Math.random()*10101)
> +"@...";
> String dupLoginId = "";
>
> /**
> * Constructs a MHHEUserRegistrarTest with the specified name.
> *
> * @param name Test case name.
> */
> public MHHERegistrarTest(String name) {
> super(name);
> }

Assuming JUnit 3.8+, this constructor is unnecessary. Delete it.

> /**
> * Sets up the test fixture.
> *
> * Called before every test case method.
> */
> protected void setUp() {
>
> mhheUsrReg = new MHHERegistrar();
> userAccount = new UserAccount();
>
> }
>
> /**
> * Tears down the test fixture.
> *
> * Called after every test case method.
> */
> protected void tearDown() {
> mhheUsrReg = null;
> userAccount = null;
>
> }
>
> /**
> * Test to see whether the randomly created user_id is
> registered only if the id is new.
> */
> public void testRegisterUser() {
> dupLoginId = newLoginId;

This line is probably wrong. I assume you want dupLoginId to be a
"snapshot" of newLoginId. Right now, they refer to the same physical
string, so a change through one reference will be seen through the
second reference. This is not a mistake using JUnit; this is a basic
misconception with Java. Please search the web for "Java alias problem".

Try dupLoginId = new String(newLoginId), a rare instance where you
actually /want/ to copy a string.

> userAccount.setLoginId(newLoginId);
>
>
> try {
> assertEquals(false,
> UMSIntegrator.checkUserInUmsbyLoginId(newLoginId));
> assertEquals(false,
> ERightsIntegrator.userExistsInErights(newLoginId));
> }
> catch (UMSException ue) {
> ue.printStackTrace();
> }
>
> mhheUsrReg.registerUser(userAccount);
> try {
> assertEquals
> (true,UMSIntegrator.checkUserInUmsbyLoginId(newLoginId));
> assertEquals
> (true,ERightsIntegrator.userExistsInErights(newLoginId));
> }
> catch (UMSException e) {
> e.printStackTrace();
> }
>
> }
>
> /**
> * Tests whether exceptions are raised if a previously
> registered user attempts to register again.
> */
> public void testRegisterDuplicatedUser() {
> System.out.println("dupLoginId---> " + dupLoginId);
> userAccount.setLoginId(dupLoginId);
>
> System.out.println("This is the user_id from
> useraccount---> "+userAccount.getLoginId());
> System.out.println("This is the user_id---
> > "+dupLoginId);
>
> try {
> System.out.println("This is user_id from
> UMSInteg ---> "+UMSIntegrator.checkUserInUmsbyLoginId(dupLoginId));
> System.out.println("This is user_id from
> ErightsInteg ---> "+ERightsIntegrator.userExistsInErights
> (dupLoginId));
> assertEquals(true,
> UMSIntegrator.checkUserInUmsbyLoginId(dupLoginId));
> assertEquals(true,
> ERightsIntegrator.userExistsInErights(dupLoginId));
> //fail("tail hasn't caused an exception when
> it should");
> }
> catch (UMSException de) {
> de.printStackTrace();
> }
>
> try
> {
> mhheUsrReg.registerUser(userAccount);
> //fail("tail hasn't caused an exception when
> it should");
> }
> catch (Exception e)
> {
> }
>
>
>
> }
>
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(MHHERegistrarTest.class);
> return suite;
> }

This method is unnecessary. Delete it.

> public static void main(String args[]) {
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> }
> }
>
>
>
>
